block.p: It seems as if every few years the math gurus insist on reinventing the wheel and making it more square (''The New, Flexible Math Meets Parental Rebellion,'' front page, April 27).
It seems as if every few years the math gurus insist on reinventing the wheel and making it more square (''The New, Flexible Math Meets Parental Rebellion,'' front page, April 27).
It took me 12 seconds to do the simple addition shown in your front-page example by the new math, while doing it by the traditional method took only 4.

At a time when we worry that the school day and the school year are too short, should we be taking up so much more of students' time with laborious solutions when shorter methods that have stood the test of time are available?
Let the pupils who cannot memorize the multiplication tables count coins, but don't deny the others the fruits of centuries of progress.
As to estimating rather than computing precise answers, I hope none of these students plan to be engineers.
LOIS TAYLOR Old Greenwich, Conn., April 27, 2000
